section.title: Updating Your Appliance
section.para: Maintaining your appliance through updates is the final process step. There are two reasons to rerun the systembuilder command and update your appliance. You may update the appliance repositories on the build server from the mirrors. Or you may redefine your appliance. Depending upon what, if anything, you update in the appliance, updates can occur on the SystemBuilder build system, the download server and the client system.

section.title: Running systembuilder to check for repository updates
section.para: To include updated packages from the repositories, execute systembuilder with the samba-server.appliance file. Rerunning systembuilder with the same .appliance file will dramatically reduce the build time, assuming there are no changes to the file's contents. SystemBuilder uses a cache of the packages and verifies the cache contents against the metadata for the repository and the groups. The screen output below shows the results of a build with no changes to the samba-server.appliance file and no updates to the repositories.

para.screen: Reading '/home/systembuilder/samba-server.appliance' Starting build of 'samba-server-5-i386' at 2008-10-25 18:29:55 Build complete at 2008-10-25 18:30:26

section.para: Since there were no updates, systembuilder completed successfully in less than two minutes. (Results will vary depending upon your SystemBuilder build system's hardware configuration.) Only if something had changed would systembuilder have rerun the repository updates and provided more detail about this build.
Unless you change the log level or the contents of the .appliance file, systembuilder will append the minimal output above to the log file.

note.para: SystemBuilder's default behavior is to append all build output to the systembuilder.log file in the /var/log directory. To redirect the output for a particular build, use the systembuilder command
where $MYLOGFILE is the new name of the log file.

section.para: If there are updates, then systembuilder will include those updated packages in the appliance repository on the build system.

important.para: If the published distribution location is the same, systembuilder updates the distribution, adding new files and replacing old ones.

section.title: Modifying the system definition file
section.para: If you change the .appliance file, then you need to rerun systembuilder. You may redefine your appliance in a plethora of ways. Some of the more common options could include selecting different repositories; including or excluding groups, packages or custom files (configuration files, scripts or triggers); or defining a new destination for the published appliance.

If you change the main/name, main/version or main/arch child elements, then you are creating a new appliance with a new $SYSTEMID and published download server location matching the new parameters. To avoid confusion between the different appliances, save the new .appliance file with a new name.

section.title: Updating the client system's appliance installation
section.para: If there are changes to the appliance on the build system, you will need to update the installed client system using yum update. For this example build, log on as the root user and execute the yum update command.

Using the yum update command will update all packages on the client system from the download server, including the appliance-specific config and release RPMs created by SystemBuilder. For more information about what these RPMs contain and how to customize their contents, see the config-rpm and release-rpm TLEs in the SDFR.
To see what changed on the client system, check the yum.log file in the /var/log/ directory.
